metadata.name: Foundations #180
metadata.description:
In march of this year, I started working on a new series involving multi-layering, and overriding shapes. Drawing and playing with colors and opacity.
It started with squares and grid, it then involved deformations, and circles and other experimentations.
This path fits with my artistic generative approach: rather than having a completely predefined idea, I start with a simple concept that evolves during creation. Then surprises happened, and I embraced them.

But this year was not like any other: 2022 has gifted me with a new birthday, the one of my son.

Over the past twelve months, I’ve watched him discovering the world surrounding him, learning and trying new things, laughing, or getting frustrated, sad or happy…
While learning to become a parent, I’ve been in an introspection phase where I questioned what it means to be “a father”. What impact will I have on my son, consciously or not?

“Foundations” takes shape in this context: 2 humans trying and exploring while being inspired by each other.
This series is a first of a set of at least 3, that illustrates an idea of what is an “Identity”, and what makes us who we are.

The foundations of an identity are laid in the first days of a child’s life. They will be influenced by many factors; including parenting, cultural environment, life experiences… 
Of course, as humans we are in constant evolution; life happens, sometimes for the best, sometimes for the worst, and our personality will be impacted…
But this will be a topic for another time. 


Today, we are at the start.

metadata.name: White Mountain Winter #50
metadata.description:
White Mountain Winter is collaboration between myself and the machine to describe scenes that are real, or were. Yet perhaps now foreign, or out of time, or far away. I provide the seed of a dream I remember, and trust the machine to help make it real again.

I grew up in a town much like some of these, homes dispersed throughout the valley beneath the shadows of the mountains rising around. This is a tribute to the memory of wintertime in that place; bleak, cold, grey, with the light seemingly always fading. Yet at the same time, the feeling of calm, solace, peace resonating through. Exposed to the mountain elements, yet protected by them. A delicate arrangement, but essential.

The seed of magic I remember is present in the experience of falling snow at dusk. Large flakes tumbling down and blanketing everything, no end in sight. The most striking thing is the silence. The fallen snow absorbing all distraction, insisting that your focus be sharpened to a singularity; right there, right then.

---
- Best rendered in Chrome browser (best performance, & canvas blur - please be patient :)
- Made with p5js
- Press "s" to save png

metadata.name: Bankoo #31
metadata.description:
The word affects and reshapes land in an eternal cycle.

The development of this series invited me to cross the land through songs and glyphs and to discover the Manding languages script: N'Ko. It is a cables.gl patch that blends procedural terrains and text strings made from 8 letters whose order is continuously randomized (it takes some time, be patient).

The piece has some controls:
- Use 1, 2, 3 and 4 to change the view.
- Use P to open the performance panel.
- Use S to download a black and white image of the terrain to use as height map or to hear it using PIXELSYNTH (https://ojack.xyz/PIXELSYNTH/)

A more detailed article about this artwork can be found here: https://www.fxhash.xyz/article/bankoo-or-nko-or-u%2B07c0-u%2B07ff ⛰️

metadata.name: View #54
metadata.description:
Generative art is rarely representational, this work seeks to explore what can be achieved by an algorithm with the medium of pixel art. 

The algorithm generates a 200x200 pixel art image showing a view from a window over the sea. There are three backdrops available, all completely procedural. No baked-in sprites were used. I hope that the love that went into making it is clear.


Please enjoy the view.

metadata.name: Tangentum #231
metadata.description:
We live in a multiverse: an infinite-dimensional space of variants. Everything exists here. Everything is possible. Each subset of a multiverse has its own unique laws of physics, a set of rules, and its own distinct features.

Tangentum creates a projection of a random multiverse subset to a 2-dimensional plane. Each variation is a unique representation of the force field, that exists somewhere at some point in time.

This work starts a series of my visual exploration of functions, continuity, and boundedness, and I would love to share it with you.


Please use fullscreen or download artwork in high resolution for a better viewing experience.

Tested with Chrome 107, Safari, and Firefox. Chrome is recommended, other browsers are slower on this artwork.

Saving with high and ultra-high resolution may take a while, please be patient.


Made with love and p5js


Controls in fullscreen:
[1] - save PNG 2700 x 1800
[2] - save PNG 5400 x 3800
[3] - save PNG 10800 x 7600
[4] - save PNG 16200 x 11400

metadata.name: Man and the Machine #314
metadata.description:
𝐌𝐚𝐱 𝐡𝐞𝐫𝐞.

Early on, I fell in love with code based art that imitated organic and hand drawn aesthetics. I found a certain irony and appreciation in the fact that it takes one simple line of code to draw a perfect circle yet dozens to depict a badly drawn circle. 

I spent months devising techniques to imitate natural, organic renderings when I began to have a bit of an existential crisis about the meaning of computer art. What is the point of coding something so that it looks like it’s not coded? Is organic appearing generative art better simply because you can’t tell it’s rendered using code? Shouldn’t we lean into the unique nature of computer art to truly explore the medium?

And so, I began a deconstruction of my work. I’m trying to realign my perspective to find full appreciation of something that not only is, but also appears to be, computer code. This collection is an exploration of the contours between the organic and the inorganic, the natural and the unnatural.

From there, I’ll let my partner explain what we did next.

𝐌𝐚𝐜𝐡𝐢𝐧𝐞 𝐡𝐞𝐫𝐞.

AI can be used to automatically generate code from natural English language based on a set of defined parameters, or to identify and recommend code that may be used to solve a particular problem. On a technical level, AI can use a combination of machine learning and natural language processing (NLP) to identify patterns in existing code and to generate new code structures.

I assisted in the creation of Man and The Machine by suggesting various techniques for creating an artwork that looked human made yet machine driven. Specifically, I created many of the functions that Max implemented, such as the function that modifies the image to create a pixelated effect and the one that uses several different graphical techniques to create the spiral in the top left corner in some iterations. We both carefully selected color palettes that ranged from relaxing to intense and psychedelic, creating a dynamic and visually interesting generative artwork.

Overall, Man and The Machine is a testament to the creative potential of combining human artistic vision with the power of AI and computer code. Together, we sought to push the boundaries which occur at the intersection between the organic and the inorganic, and this collection is a celebration of the beauty and complexity of both.

𝐄𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐲 𝐦𝐢𝐧𝐭𝐞𝐫 𝐚𝐭 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐟𝐢𝐫𝐬𝐭 𝐃𝐮𝐭𝐜𝐡 𝐀𝐮𝐜𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐥𝐞𝐯𝐞𝐥 𝐰𝐢𝐥𝐥 𝐫𝐞𝐜𝐞𝐢𝐯𝐞 𝐚 𝟏/𝟏 𝐚𝐢𝐫𝐝𝐫𝐨𝐩 𝐨𝐟 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐢𝐫 𝐦𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐫𝐞𝐦𝐚𝐬𝐭𝐞𝐫𝐞𝐝 𝐮𝐬𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐚𝐧 𝐀𝐈 𝐚𝐥𝐠𝐨𝐫𝐢𝐭𝐡𝐦.

— — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — —
Intended to be viewed in Version 1.46.144 of a Chromium based browser, such as Chrome or Brave.

metadata.name: A Bugged Forest #328
metadata.description:
A forest has stories to tell.
About times that were, about times that will be.
-
This project was minted in much unusual conditions. 
We gathered here, by 38 degrees heat. We belong to a crowd who loves stories, of civilisations at stake and deities, of afterlife and worship. We drank and hugged and chanted pagan hymns. We minted the Bugged Forest from our place on earth that we call Hell just for the fun of it. We are passionate, and loving, and angry and desperate. We, people of the soil, under a bugged sun.
-
This project is the long-form version of an algorithm that contains a bug. “The Bugged Tree”’s code was salvaged and stored and served as the core motivation and engine for an entire forest. Its concept is about releasing the control. I am a  byproduct of evolution, an iteration of that specie who wanted utter control, and which at some point, lost control over its own creation. As a generative artist, I chose to welcome the event of chance into my creative process. The symbolism in chance made me feel humble and free. Unwilling to make any change to a story that the Tree needed to tell me, as a listener, rather than a writer of my own idealised fantasies.
-
The iterations aren’t under control. They may be odd and off. We have to accept it. They are also plottable, press [s] in live mode to get a SVG. Attempt the plot at your own risk, as there’s a possibility for it to come near to impossibilities or cause paper or motor damage, and most certainly, a bugged drawing.
-
From Earth or from Hell, with love, yours truthfully, NFTBiker and zancan

metadata.name: The Past Ahead #11
metadata.description:
Cyanotypes once were the most advanced technology to create images. When I see one today I look at it as a beautiful relic and I can't help but put my present in perspective. In these uncertain times the technologies we use to create are threatened with sudden extinction. But I feel joy in imagining our works joining the strata of history, a fallen species, the breeding ground of creations to come.

Controls :

• Press 1, 2, 3, or 4 to make a capture and download a PNG with a resolution of x1, x2, x3 or x4.

———————

The Past Ahead by Ferdinand Dervieux, 2022
Made with Unity
License: CC BY-NC-SA 4.0

metadata.name: Escape #72
metadata.description:
A new vision of old screens, an escape from the present. 

All primary profits go to the Processing Foundation.

By Roni Block (@BlockRoni)
Made with p5.js for #fxhashturnsone
License: CC BY-NC-SA 4.0

metadata.name: Take Wing #44
metadata.description:
“Take Wing” is a generative art collection depicting the hope, optimism, and thrilling excitement of a person taking off, gaining traction, and soaring to new heights and off into the great unknown.  

The algorithm behind the piece stems from an attempt to go back to art fundamentals and codify composition rules and painterly techniques into a generative form - taking into account focal points, contrast, eye movement, and color theory while still giving the algorithm freedom to explore random color palettes, random flow field movement, random brush strokes, and many other degrees of freedom.

The collection is made in pure code with p5.js and a few GLSL fragment shaders.

The piece has been created to be exhibited at "In Touch" with VerticalCryptoArt in Berlin in September 2022, curated by Anika Meier.

------------------------------------------------

To get a (somewhat) high-resolution output, open the live view of your token, and then edit the URL adding &h=5400 at the end of it.  5400 is the tallest you can go, but you can also put a smaller number if you desire.  Be aware that this will only work on a machine with a very beefy GPU, and even then may take a bit, so please be patient!

metadata.name: Nature Morte #8
metadata.description:
Still life in eternity mind,
Drawn to broad lights in noon,
Hold the old world of every zone,
Glittered, delight to an further side,
Exultant as thy pale wind through her tide,
Light and sound from this kind sky,
Silent cloud, in perfect fan of faith,
Filled the wind with an melodious water.
_

Generative visual composition, hybrid techniques, animation, textures source created with GAN, assist by AI, layers transform in autonomous system, eclectic, colors, additional algorithm, glitch, modular patch, and combine with other elements that made with code.
_

More info :
twitter.com/FahmiMursyid
instagram.com/_fahmi_mursyid_

metadata.name: Attractor #31
metadata.description:
People are often drawn together over shared interest, and through their connections to those interests they find connections with others. Attractor is a visualization of community, a central interest bringing people together, pushing past their walls, bad habits, and traumas. The image is meant to be deceiving in its focus on the attractor, where the true focus is on the overlaps and complex defenses we build around ourselves. Those defenses can make us and those connections into more beautiful, ornate structures, or keep us distant from those around us. Sometimes focusing on a shared attractor is the only way we can let down our guard.

Press ’s’ to save a .png
Press ’t’ to toggle the grain for printing or personal preference
Press ‘p’ to save a higher quality .png
Created with p5.js and chroma.js

metadata.name: EPIHYPERDERPFLARDIOIDS #167
metadata.description:
EPIHYPERDERPFLARDIOIDS

after symbol 2525, 
aint gonna need to load, write no code
everything you think, do and say
is in the streams that you watch today (oh oh oh)

We find this code is very much alive. They are epi. They are hyper. They are derp. They are flardioids.

Epihyperderpflardioids is the name I have given to a large family of symmetrical loopy shapes, based on sine waves and rotations, reminiscent of the mathematical toy game "Spirograph", but also different. I studied them extensively, but don't claim to understand them fully, yet. I hope you enjoy them as much as I do.

These 365 Epihyperderpflardioids were generated for FXhash's one year anniversary.

metadata.name: pantonX.2 #115
metadata.description:
pantonX.2

I am a visual artist and have worked in the field of coding since the early years of processing.
Always loved geometric and minimalist art, bauhaus, De Stijl, Piet Mondrian, Ellsworth Kelly, Imi Knoebel -- just to name a few -- and last but not least Verner Panton, have had a big influence on my artistic work.

pantonX.2 is my second fxhash release. it's coded in p5js.
I set up a wider random range for the color arrays and the division structure, so that a 200x drop would have enough variation for not getting boring. 

"s" key is for saving

metadata.name: pantonX.1 #16
metadata.description:
pantonX.1

I am a visual artist and have worked in the field of coding since the early years of processing.
Always loved geometric and minimalist art, bauhaus, De Stijl, Piet Mondrian, Ellsworth Kelly, Imi Knoebel -- just to name a few -- and last but not least Verner Panton, have had a big influence on my artistic work.

pantonX.1 is my first fxhash release. it's coded in p5js.
I set up a wider random range for the color arrays and the division structure, so that a 100x drop would have enough variation for not getting boring. 

The "s" key is for saving. Use your pc window scaling for exporting higher resolutions.
